justifications: If Bernie Sanders supporters can learn anything from Brexit, it is that the English-speaking world is in the mood for a certain type of right-wing populism.
When the 2016 campaign started, Clinton had not taken a firm stance on the Trans-Pacific Partnership, but since then she has made it clear that she will oppose the agreement.
While Trump has tried to claim that she initially supported the deal and only switched positions because of him, Clinton's position is actually consistent with what she wrote in her memoir.
Clinton, on the other hand, would increase taxes on wealthier Americans.
The centerpiece of Trump's tax plan is to replace America's seven tax rates with three.
All of these policies would benefit wealthier Americans and would most likely force the government to take money away from programs which help the working class.
Trump, not Clinton, has flip-flopped on this issue.
Clinton's support for a $12 minimum wage may not go as far as Sanders' $15 proposal, it is certainly a vast improvement from Trump's ambiguousness here.
If Bernie Sanders supporters can learn anything from Brexit, it is that the English-speaking world is in the mood for a certain type of right-wing populism.
While Trump may be effective at using a certain type of populist rhetoric, his economic plans would ultimately favor the wealthy.
Clinton, though not as far to the left as Sanders, is pushing for policies that would benefit ordinary Americans.
